item.title: Dutch police identify users on Cracked.io
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Excerpts from a press release today by the Dutch Police after several investigations by the Cybercrime Team of the Zeeland-West-Brabant unit revealed that suspects had an account on the Cracked.io platform. Dutch police, in collaboration with other countries involved in Europol, were able to secure and take down servers and identify individual users. Ultimately, 126 individual...

item.title: Help, please: Seeking copies of the PowerSchool ransom email(s)
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Help, please: If anyone has a copy of the ransom note sent to PowerSchool in December 2024 or to PowerSchool clients on or about May 7, 2025, please email me a copy or upload it to me on Signal. I want to see not only the body, but the full header and signature. To reach...

item.title: RCMP thumb drive with informant, witness data obtained by criminals: watchdog
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Jim Bronskill reports: The RCMP lost a USB key containing personal information about victims, witnesses and informants, and later learned it was being offered for sale by criminals, the federal privacy watchdog says. A detailed report from the Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada reveals the RCMP told the watchdog about the breach in March...

item.title: Evoke Wellness to Pay $1.9 Million to Settle FTC Claims That They Misled Consumers Seeking Substance Use Disorder Treatment
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Evoke allegedly used Google ads and telemarketing to pretend to be other clinics; court order permanently bans them from similar deceptive conduct On June 10, DataBreaches sent Evoke Wellness in Hilliard, Ohio an inquiry about an insider-wrongdoing breach reported in Ohio media but not mentioned on their website. There has been no reply as of...

item.title: Former Hilliard treatment center employee accused of selling patient data on dark web
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: In case you were looking for yet another reminder of the insider threat in the healthcare sector, here’s a report from WBNS in Ohio: Authorities in Hilliard are investigating a widespread fraud and identity theft case involving a former employee of a local addiction treatment center who allegedly sold patients’ private data on the dark...

item.title: Trump Rewrites Cybersecurity Policy in Executive Order
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: David Perera reports: President Donald Trump signed Friday an executive order reframing U.S. cybersecurity policy, eliminating what the Republican White House described as “problematic elements” inherited from Democratic administrations. The new order strikes a push for digital identity documents made by then-President Joe Biden in one of his last acts as commander in chief. Digital IDs, the White House...

item.title: AMI Group – Travel & Tours notice of ransomware attack
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: The following notice was posted June 3 on Facebook. As of publication, there is no notice on their website, and although AMI indicates that APT73 is responsible for the attack, there is nothing on Bashe’s leak site or any other leak site. 𝗨𝗥𝗚𝗘𝗡𝗧 𝗣𝗨𝗕𝗟𝗜𝗖 𝗡𝗢𝗧𝗜𝗖𝗘 – 𝗖𝗬𝗕𝗘𝗥𝗦𝗘𝗖𝗨𝗥𝗜𝗧𝗬 𝗔𝗟𝗘𝗥𝗧 𝗧𝗼 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲𝗱 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀, 𝗽𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗻𝗲𝗿𝘀, 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗲𝗵𝗼𝗹𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀, 𝗮𝗻𝗱...

item.title: Resource: Insider Threat reports
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: On a daily or weekly basis, DataBreaches highlights insider wrongdoing incidents and the harm they can cause. For more comprehensive compilation and analysis of the topic, readers may be interested in the Insider Threat Incidents For May 2025 report produced by the National Insider Threat Special Interest Group and Insider Threat Defense Group. Their previous...

item.title: Za: Cyber extortionist sentenced to eight years in jail
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Admire Moyo reports on an insider wrongdoing case in South Africa: In a landmark case, a man was last week sentenced to eight years in jail for contravening South Africa’s Cyber Crimes Act. Lucky Majangandile Erasmus (36), a former employee of Ecentric Payment Systems, was sentenced by the Specialised Commercial Crimes Court after entering into...

item.title: ICE takes steps to deport the Australian hacker known as “DR32”
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: David Kee Crees has been detained by Denver Homeland Security – ICE to be deported. The Australian national was recently released from a federal prison after pleading guilty to hacking and other charges. The strange case of “DR32” just got a bit stranger. It looks like the Australian national will get a plane ticket back...
